org.sd.text
Class WordGramStat

java.lang.Object
  org.sd.text.WordGramStat

public class WordGramStat
extends java.lang.Object

Thread-safe container for aggretating stats for word N-grams (for one N).

Author:
Spence Koehler

Use default automatic pruning parameters.

WordGramStat

public WordGramStat(int n,
                    WordGramSplitter splitter,
                    int ngramLimit,
                    int stdDevs,
                    long pruneTimeInterval)
Collect stats for N-grams using the given WordGramSplitter.

Parameters:
n - The 'n' in word N-gram (number of words)
splitter - The WordGramSplitter to use
ngramLimit - The maximum number of ngrams to hold before attempting to prune. If 0, then no maximum or automatic pruning will take place.
stdDevs - Pruning parameter when limit is reached. Only ngrams that have a frequency greater N standard deviations from the mean will be kept.
pruneTimeInterval - Time interval to wait between attempts to prune.

WordGramStat

public WordGramStat(int n)
Construct an instance for reconstruction.

NOTE: The add(string) and flush methods will be disabled and only the add(NGramFreq) and getter methods will work.

setNgram2Freq

public void setNgram2Freq(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,NGramFreq> ngram2freq)
Set the frequency map.

NOTE: Using this setter will destroy any existing data in the current instance, restoring it to the state represented by the supplied ngram2freq data. It will also place this instance into "reconstruction" mode such that it will not accept string adds.

add

public void add(java.lang.String string)
Collect n-grams from the given string. (Thread safe.)

The idea is to add strings that are split into N-grams that are collected but not analyzed for statistics. Once all strings have been added, then a "flush" will add the collected N-grams to the statistical tallies.

The consumer can manually flush after every add for tallies on every string or flush after certain groups of strings have been added so that within the group, duplicates are not tallied, but across groups they are.

Returns:

getTopNGramsLimitedByCount

public NGramFreq[] getTopNGramsLimitedByCount(int num,
                                              WordGramStat.NGramAcceptor acceptor,
                                              java.util.concurrent.atomic.AtomicBoolean die)
Get the top 'num' n-grams.

Parameters:
num - Is the (maximum) number of n-grams to collect.
acceptor - (ok if null) NGramAcceptor to determine which ngrams to keep or reject while collecting.
die - Flag to monitor for a signal to terminate early (ok if null).
Returns:
up to num of the accepted top nGrams.

getFreqStats

public StatsAccumulator getFreqStats()
Get the stats (min, max, ave, etc.) of frequencies for all collected NGrams.

The returned stats have the following meaning:

  • stats.getN() -- the total number of unique ngrams collected
  • stats.getSum() -- the total number of ngrams collected
  • stats.getMean() -- the average frequency of ngrams collected
  • stats.getMin() -- the minimum frequency of ngrams collected
  • stats.getMax() -- the maximum frequency of ngrams collected

The probability of any ngram occurring is: p(ngram) = ngram.getFreq() / stats.getSum();

getTopNGrams

public final NGramFreq[] getTopNGrams(int countLimit,
                                      int minFreq,
                                      WordGramStat.NGramAcceptor acceptor,
                                      java.util.concurrent.atomic.AtomicBoolean die)
Get the top n-grams.

NOTE: If a timeLimit is set for this instance, then the timeLimit will be applied while collapsing the NGrams and the 'die' parameter will be ignored.

Parameters:
countLimit - The largest number to collect (unlimited if <= 0).
minFreq - The minimum frequency to collect (no minimum if <= 0).
acceptor - A function to test each ngram for inclusion.
die - Flag to monitor for a signal to terminate early (ok if null).
